thread.title: Young Guns of NASCAR Daytona 500 paint schemes and results | FOX Sports
thread.title_full: Young Guns of NASCAR Daytona 500 paint schemes and results | FOX Sports

author: Tim Durr
title: Young Guns of NASCAR Daytona 500 paint schemes and results | FOX Sports
text:
Feb 3, 2017 at 12:31p ET 0Shares 
The future of the Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series has quite a few bright spots who will be looking to capture the Harley J. Earl Trophy in the 59 th running of the Daytona 500 on Feb. 26 on FOX. 
Check out the paint schemes and results of NASCAR’s youth movement (Kyle Larson, Austin Dillon, Chase Elliott, Ryan Blaney, and Chris Buescher): Getty Images Getty Images 2013, Austin Dillon 
Of all the young drivers on this list, Dillon has made the most starts in the Daytona 500. Before he moved into the No. 3 full-time, he drove a limited schedule in 2013 in the No. 33. He started eighth in the Great American Race but limped home to a 31 st -place finish. Brian Czobat / autostock © 271 Fryling Ave SW Concord, NC 28025 W 704.786.2919 C 704.904.2745 autostock/Brian Czobat 2014, Austin Dillon 
In his first race in the iconic No. 3 Chevrolet for his grandfather, Richard Childress, Dillon put the car on the pole it the first race with the car number since Dale Earnhardt’s death at the track in 2001. Dillon finished ninth after a strong starting spot. © , Michael L. Levitt © 2014, Michael L. Levitt 2014, Kyle Larson 
Larson posted a solid starting spot of 16 th in his first appearance but an accident put him out of the race in 38 th . © John Harrelson John K Harrelson / LAT Photo USA 2015, Austin Dillon 
In Dillon’s second Daytona 500 appearance, he started much farther back than his previous appearance. Dillon climbed his way from a 30 th starting spot to a 14 th -place finish. Getty Images Getty Images 2015, Kyle Larson 
It was a similar story for Larson in his second 500. After starting 29 th , he struggled most of the race and ended up one lap down in 39 th when the checkered flag waved. NASCAR Getty Images via Getty Images 2015, Ryan Blaney 
Before going full-time with the Wood Brothers, Blaney appeared on a limited basis in 2015 and started 12 th in the 500. His day was cut short with engine trouble that led to a 39 th -place finish. Getty Images Getty Images 2016, Chase Elliott 
Elliott became another rookie pole winner at Daytona but his day turned south when he wrecked and limped around to a 37 th -place finish. John Harrelson / LAT Photo USA 2016, Chris Buescher 
In his debut with the No. 34 Front Row Motorsports Ford, Buescher started in 17 th but a Lap 91 accident ended his day in 39 th . 2016, Austin Dillon 
Dillon started last year’s Daytona 500 in 21 st and climbed through the field to a ninth-place finish, tying his best of his career. 2016, Kyle Larson 
The third time was a charm for Larson in the Daytona 500. He didn’t end up with a win but made major improvements from his first two starts. Larson started the race in 14 th and posted his first top-10 with a seventh-place finish. 2016, Ryan Blaney 
With Wood Brothers Racing going back to a full-time schedule for the first time in almost 10 years, Blaney started off the season on a bright note with a strong performance in the Gatorade Duels race that translated to a seventh-place starting spot and a 19 th -place result.
